content.text: 1 A student determines the internal diameter \(d\) of a test-tube.
The apparatus is assembled as shown in Fig. 1.1.
(a) The student:
- fills a measuring cylinder with water up to the \(100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) mark - pours some water from the measuring cylinder into the test-tube.
(i) A full-size diagram of the bottom part of the test-tube is shown in Fig. 1.2.
On Fig. 1.2, measure the height \(h\) in centimetres to the nearest millimetre.
Record your result in the top row of Table 1.1 on page 4.
(ii) Fig. 1.3 shows the volume of water remaining in the measuring cylinder.
Take the reading \(R\) of the volume of water remaining in the measuring cylinder.
Record your result in the top row of Table 1.1.
(iii) Calculate the volume \(V\) of water poured into the test-tube.
Use the equation:
Record your result in Table 1.1.

table.html:
\(h / \mathrm{cm}\)
\(R / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\)
\(V / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\)
5.0
84

7.6

47

content.text: (b) The student:
- adds more water from the measuring cylinder into the test-tube - measures the new height \(h\) of the water in the test-tube
- measures the new reading \(R\) of the water remaining in the measuring cylinder - calculates the volume of water \(V\) in the test-tube
- repeats the procedure for three more values of \(h, R\) and \(V\).
The student's results are shown in Table 1.1.
It is important to avoid line-of-sight (parallax) errors when reading the scale of the measuring cylinder.
Describe how such errors are avoided. You may draw a diagram.
(c) Plot a graph of \(V / \mathrm{cm}^{3}\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(h / \mathrm{cm}\) ( \(x\)-axis). Start your axes at the origin \((0,0)\).
Draw the best-fit straight line.
(d) Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show all working and indicate on the graph the values you use.
(e) (i) The internal diameter \(d\) of a cylinder is given by the equation \(d=k \sqrt{G}\), where \(k=1.13 \mathrm{~cm}\).
Calculate \(d\) for the test-tube.
cm [1]
(ii) Suggest one reason why your calculated value for \(d\) is only approximate.
2 A student investigates a light-dependent resistor (LDR).
The student assembles a series circuit consisting of a power supply, a switch, a \(470 \Omega\) resistor and an LDR.
(a) Fig. 2.1 shows part of the circuit that the student assembles.
Complete the circuit by adding the correct symbol for an LDR between Y and Z . Choose from the list provided in Fig. 2.2.
(b) (i) The student:
- closes the switch - connects a voltmeter across the \(470 \Omega\) resistor
- records the reading on the voltmeter - opens the switch.
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the \(470 \Omega\) resistor.
(ii) The voltmeter reading is shown in Fig. 2.3.
Record the voltmeter reading \(V_{X Y}\).
(c) The current \(I\) in the circuit is calculated using the equation:
where \(R=470 \Omega\).
Use your voltmeter reading in (b)(ii) to calculate the current \(I\).
(d) The student:
- closes the switch - connects the voltmeter between points Y and Z
- records the voltmeter reading \(V_{Y Z}\) - opens the switch.
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the LDR in bright light using the equation:
(e) (i) The student covers the LDR with a piece of card and repeats the procedure described in (b) and (d).
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{D}}\) of the LDR in the dark using the equation:
\Omega [1]
(ii) The student removes the card from the top of the LDR and slowly lifts it vertically upwards away from the LDR until the card is 30 cm above the LDR. The student observes and
records the readings on the voltmeter across the LDR ( \(V_{Y Z}\) ) as the card is raised.
Table 2.1 shows the student's results.

content.text: Describe how the p.d. across the LDR ( \(V_{Y Z}\) ) changes as the distance between the card and the LDR increases.
(f) When the LDR is covered by the card, the current in the circuit changes.
Use the student's results from (b)(ii), (d) and (e)(i) to show how this change in current affects the value of the total potential difference ( \(V_{X Y}+V_{Y Z}\) ).
3 A student investigates the image formed by a converging lens.
Refer to Fig. 3.1.
(a) The student:
- switches on the lamp - places the screen a distance \(D=80.0 \mathrm{~cm}\) from the illuminated object (a triangular hole in
a piece of card) - places the lens close to the illuminated object
- moves the lens away from the illuminated object until a magnified, inverted, sharp image of the illuminated object is formed on the screen.
Fig. 3.1 shows the position of the lens when the image is sharp.
(i) On Fig. 3.1, measure, to the nearest 0.1 cm , the object distance \(x\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.
cm [1]
(ii) Fig. 3.1 is drawn to a scale of one-fifth full size.
Calculate the actual object distance \(X\).
cm [1]
(b) The student:
- continues to move the lens away from the illuminated object until a second sharp image, which is diminished and inverted, is formed on the screen
- measures, to the nearest 0.1 cm , the object distance \(Y\) from the centre of the lens to the illuminated object.
(i) Fig. 3.2 shows the illuminated object.
On Fig. 3.2, draw a diminished, inverted image in the space provided.
illuminated object image
(ii) Calculate the value \(d=(Y-X)\).
(c) The focal length \(f\) of the lens can be found using the equation:
Use the value of \(D\) from (a) and \(d\) from (b)(ii) to calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens.
Give your answer to 3 significant figures.
(d) The student repeats the procedure in (a) and (b) for an object to screen distance \(D=100.0 \mathrm{~cm}\).
The student records the values of \(X, Y\) and \(d\).
(f) (i) State one technique to use when doing this type of experiment to ensure that the image on the screen is focused as clearly as possible.
(ii) This experiment is usually done in a darkened room.
Explain how this makes it easier to see when the image is in focus.
4 Hot water is poured into a glass beaker and allowed to cool down for 5 minutes.
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the rate of cooling of the hot water depends upon the initial temperature of the hot water.
The rate of cooling of the water can be calculated using the equation:

content.blockMath:
\[
\text { rate of cooling }=\frac{\text { decrease in temperature }}{\text { time taken }} .
\]

content.text: You are provided with:
- a supply of cold water - an electric kettle
- a \(250 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) glass beaker - a measuring cylinder.
You may use any other common laboratory apparatus.
In your plan, include:
- any other apparatus needed - a brief description of the method, including what you will measure and how you will make
sure your measurements are accurate - the variables you will control
- a results table to record your measurements (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
- how you will process your results to reach a conclusion.
You may include a labelled diagram.
